content:
Diagnosis:	Pilocytic astrocytoma of the posterior fossa

Histology:	WHO grade I pilocytic astrocytoma with KIAA1549-BRAF fusion detected

Current Situation:	Post-operative follow-up assessment

I reviewed [redacted name] today following his recent posterior fossa surgery performed by [redacted name] on 15 March 2024. The operation achieved a gross total resection of the cerebellar lesion, and post-operative MRI on day 1 confirmed no residual enhancement. Histology has confirmed a WHO grade I pilocytic astrocytoma with molecular analysis detecting the KIAA1549-BRAF fusion.

He has made an excellent post-operative recovery with gradual improvement in his presenting symptoms of headache and ataxia. The initial post-operative nausea has now completely resolved. His parents report he has returned to his normal energy levels and has resumed most daily activities. He remains off school but is keen to return.

On examination today, his surgical wound has healed well. His cranial nerve examination is normal. There is mild residual ataxia on heel-shin testing but this has significantly improved since the immediate post-operative period. His gait is now steady and he can walk unaided.

Given the complete resection and favourable histology, we have discussed that no adjuvant treatment is required. The plan is for surveillance MRI scanning, with the first scan scheduled for 3 months' time. I have provided the family with written information about pilocytic astrocytoma and answered their questions about prognosis, which is excellent given the complete resection.

We will review him again following the surveillance MRI in 3 months' time. I have also made a referral to our neuro-oncology specialist nurse who will provide ongoing support and education.
